Abstract of the bachelor’s thesis
 
Author Henrik Aalto
 
Title The Sylow Theorems and Classiﬁcation of Finite Groups
 
Degree programme Bachelor of Science in Technology
 
Major Mathematics and Operations Research Code of major SCI3029
 
Teacher in charge Prof. Kaie Kubjas
 
Advisor Prof. Kaie Kubjas
 
Date 24.4.2025 Number of pages 56+13 Language English
 
Abstract
 
A group is, by deﬁnition, a simple mathematical structure from which stems a
 
complex and fruitful branch of mathematics. Two natural examples of groups are
 
the states of the Rubik’s cube and the integers modulo
 
n
 
,
 
Z
 
n
 
. The power of groups
 
lies in their ability to eﬀectively model very fundamental systems: symmetries and
 
their combinations. Group-theoretic research has traditionally focused on the precise
 
classiﬁcation of groups. In this approach, the speciﬁc elements of a group do not
 
matter, rather, it is only the relationships among the elements that determine the
 
class of the group. The so-called ‘group axioms’ impose strict constraints on the
 
structure. By studying this structure, one obtains classiﬁcation results that have
 
direct applications in crystallography and number theory.
 
In this bachelor’s thesis, the classiﬁcation of groups of order up to 20 is examined
 
in detail, starting from the deﬁnition of a group. Central results of group theory and
 
the precise examination of the structure of small groups are central in the work. As
 
aids for classiﬁcation, additional structures related to groups are deﬁned, such as
 
subgroups and cosets. Through these, we obtain access to Sylow’s theorems and the
 
fundamental theorem of ﬁnite Abelian groups, both of which are powerful tools for
 
constraining the possibilities of classiﬁcation. On the other hand, new isomorphism
 
classes can be constructed by forming semidirect products between smaller groups.
 
With diﬀerent constructions, there is a need to distinguish between isomorphic and
 
non-isomorphic groups—a task for which comparing the sizes of normal subgroups
 
and the orders of elements proves useful. Each approach to classiﬁcation reinforces
 
our understanding of the potential realisations of groups.
 
The classiﬁcation of Abelian groups is achieved via the fundamental theorem,
 
yet even the structures of small non-Abelian groups can diﬀer markedly from one
 
another. Nonetheless, groups always adhere to certain regularities, and often some
 
additional constraint uniquely determines the remainder of the group’s structure.
 
There is one isomorphism class of groups of order seven, whereas there are ﬁve
 
isomorphism classes of groups of order eight. Thus, the number of isomorphism
 
classes does not depend directly on the order of the group. Instead, this number is
 
strongly connected to the prime factorisation of the order: the more factors a number
 
has, the more isomorphism classes of that order there are. Groups of composite order
 
can be assembled in various ways from smaller groups, while, as an extreme example,
 
every prime order corresponds to only one isomorphism class consisting solely of the
 
cyclic group. A number-theoretic approach can be further pursued by investigating
 
4
 
the isomorphism classes for groups of orders
 
pq
 
and
 
p
 
2
 
, where
 
p
 
and
 
q
 
are primes.
 
For the former, there are one or two classes, whereas for the latter there are always
 
exactly two possibilities. This result further strengthens the connection between the
 
prime factorisation of the order and the structure of the group.
 
Keywords
 
Group, Sylow’s theorems, classiﬁcation, isomorphism, Lagrange’s theorem

Tiivistelmä
 
Ryhmä on määritelmältään yksinkertainen matemaattinen rakenne, jonka pohjalta
 
rakentuu monimutkainen ja sovelluksiltaan hedelmällinen matematiikan osa-alue.
 
Luonnollisia esimerkkejä ryhmistä ovat esimerkiksi Rubikin kuution tilat sekä koko-
 
naisluvut modulo
 
n
 
,
 
Z
 
n
 
. Ryhmien hyödyllisyys piilee niiden kyvyssä mallintaa hyvin
 
perustavanlaatuisia järjestelmiä: symmetrioita ja niiden yhdistelmiä. Ryhmäteoreet-
 
tinen tutkimus on perinteisesti keskittynyt ryhmien tarkkaan luokitteluun. Tässä
 
lähestymistavassa ryhmän toteutuneella sisällöllä ei ole merkitystä, vaan sen sijaan
 
ainoastaan ryhmän alkioiden keskinäiset suhteet määräävät sen luokan. Niin kutsutut
 
ryhmälait asettavat tälle rakenteelle tiukat rajoitteet. Tätä rakennetta tutkimalla
 
saadaan luokittelutuloksia, joilla on laajasti suoria sovelluksia niin kideopissa kuin
 
lukuteoriassa.
 
Tässä kandidaatintyössä tutkitaan tarkasti kokoon 20 asti ryhmien luokittelua
 
ryhmän määritelmästä lähtien. Tärkeässä roolissa ovat työssä esiteltävät ryhmäteo-
 
rian keskeiset tulokset ja pienten ryhmien rakenteen täsmällinen tarkastelu. Luokit-
 
telun avuksi määritellään ryhmään liittyviä läheisiä rakenteita, kuten aliryhmät ja
 
sivuluokat. Näiden avulla päästään käsiksi Sylowin lauseisiin ja äärellisten Abelin
 
ryhmien luokittelun peruslauseeseen, jotka kummatkin ovat voimakkaita työkaluja
 
luokittelumahdollisuuksien rajaamiseen. Toisaalta uusia isomorﬁsmiluokkia saadaan
 
rakennettua pienempien ryhmien välisillä puolisuorilla tuloilla. Eri vaihtoehtoja raken-
 
taessa nousee esiin tarve erottaa isomorﬁset ja ei-isomorﬁset ryhmät toisistaan, mihin
 
hyödynnetään normaalien aliryhmien kokojen ja alkioiden suuruuksien vertailua.
 
Eri lähestymiset luokitteluun kukin rakentavat ymmärrystä ryhmien mahdollisista
 
realisaatioista.
 
Abelin ryhmien luokittelu onnistuu peruslauseen avulla, mutta pienienkin ei-
 
Abelin ryhmien rakenteet eroavat suuresti toisistaan. Ryhmät kuitenkin noudattavat
 
aina lainalaisuuksia, ja usein jokin reunaehto määrittää yksikäsitteisesti ryhmän
 
muun rakenteen.
 
Seitsemän kokoisia ryhmäluokkia on yksi, kun taas kahdeksan kokoisia on vii-
 
si. Isomorﬁsmiluokkien määrä ei siis riipu suoraan tarkasteltavasta ryhmäkoosta.
 
Sen sijaan tällä määrällä on vahva yhteys ryhmäkoon alkutekijähajotelmaan: mitä
 
enemmän luvulla on tekijöitä, sitä enemmän on myös sen kokoisia ryhmäluokkia.
 
Yhdistetyn luvun kokoisia ryhmiä saa eri tavoin koostettua pienemmistä ryhmistä,
 
kun taas ääriesimerkkinä kaikkia alkulukukokoja vastaa vain yksi syklisestä ryh-
 
mästä koostuva isomorﬁsmiryhmä. Lukuteoreettista lähestymistapaa voidaan jatkaa
 
6
 
tutkimalla isomorﬁsmiluokkia ryhmäkoille
 
pq
 
ja
 
p
 
2
 
, missä
 
p
 
ja
 
q
 
ovat alkulukuja. En-
 
simmäiselle on yksi tai kaksi luokkaa, kun taas toiselle on aina kaksi mahdollisuutta.
 
Tämä entisestään vahvistaa luokkamäärien ja koon alkutekijähajotelman yhteyttä.
 
Avainsanat Ryhmä, Sylowin lauseet, luokittelu, isomorﬁsmi, Lagrangen lause

1 Introduction
 
Symmetry is a fundamental principle with immense applications. It appears through-
 
out natural sciences, especially in the study of mathematics.
 
A group is the mathematical model for symmetry. The concept of an abstract
 
group has appeared in a variety of ﬁelds of mathematics and science since the 19th
 
century. Groups can represent any set of objects that when combined yield another
 
object from the same set, given that combining is associative, that there is an identity
 
object which leaves all objects unchanged and that each combination is invertible.
 
For concreteness, we introduce an example group: the symmetries of a square. A
 
square can be ﬂipped or rotated, without changing the shape. These symmetries
 
can be combined to get new symmetries. This symmetry group, also known as the
 
dihedral group D
 
8
 
, has eight elements.
 
While the elements of a group can take any form, the crucial property is how
 
they are related to each other. We are interested in classifying groups of diﬀerent
 
structures. Two groups are considered the same if one can be turned into the other
 
by renaming elements. It is fruitful to concentrate on classifying small ﬁnite groups,
 
since this knowledge can, then, be applied to studying larger, even inﬁnite, groups.
 
For this reason, the classiﬁcation of ﬁnite groups is a signiﬁcant area of mathematics
 
that has been active since the 19th century. Known mathematicians such as Évariste
 
Galois, Joseph Lagrange, and William Burnside have contributed to group theory. A
 
detailed history appears in Section 2.
 
Motivated by the focus on ﬁnite groups, we now state the precise aims of this
 
work. This thesis classiﬁes all ﬁnite groups of orders 1 to 20, except for the order
 
16, up to isomorphism, providing representatives of each type and proving that the
 
classiﬁcation is complete. While classiﬁcations of groups appear in the literature, this
 
thesis aims to provide a self-contained and accessible account of small groups. We
 
develop the foundations of group theory by studying smaller groups in more detail in
 
order to better understand larger ones. For the classiﬁcation of larger groups, more
 
powerful theorems are deployed, which in turn deepen our understanding. We aim
 
to provide a coherent and comprehensive classiﬁcation with a strong emphasis on
 
discussing and analysing the results. Our goal is to convey a solid understanding of
 
the structure of small groups in addition to a grip on the most important results of
 
group theory.
 
This work begins with the abstract deﬁnition of a group. To better study groups,
 
we introduce other key structures such as subgroups and cosets. The two most
 
important theorems in group theory, Lagrange’s theorem and the Sylow theorems,
 
are presented and applied to the classiﬁcation of groups. Through constructions like
 
direct and semidirect products we are able to create new groups which is studied
 
using the theory of isomorphisms. We also classify certain inﬁnite families of groups,
 
based on the number-theoretic structure of their order. Moreover, we present the
 
fundamental theorem of ﬁnite Abelian groups that classiﬁes all ﬁnite Abelian groups.
 
For the groups, we have classiﬁed, we provide concise and fruitful descriptions by
 
providing their presentation.
 
The structure of the work is as follows. Chapter 2 provides a detailed account
 
11
 
of the two-century-long history of the classiﬁcation of ﬁnite groups. Chapter 3
 
introduces fundamental results and structures from group theory, starting from
 
the deﬁnition of a group. Chapter 4 begins the actual classiﬁcation, providing the
 
rigorous classiﬁcation of groups of orders 1–10. Following that, Chapter 5 introduces
 
more powerful theorems and tools needed for further classiﬁcation. Those tools
 
are then used in Chapter 6 to classify groups of orders 11–20. The results of the
 
classiﬁcation are presented in Chapter 7. Finally, Chapter 8 gives a summary of the
 
classiﬁcation process and discusses methods, key ﬁndings and implications.
 
2 Historical Background
 
The study of groups began indirectly through the study of polynomial equations in
 
the 18th century. After group-like structures had been introduced in several other
 
ﬁelds, the rigorous study of groups on their own began shortly after [
 
20
 
]. Notably,
 
Évariste Galois studied the solutions of polynomial equations by radicals. Galois
 
realised that the permutation symmetries of the roots of a polynomial equation
 
determined whether the equation is solvable by radicals. To this end, he introduced
 
the concept of a simple group, which is a group that has no non-trivial normal
 
subgroups [31].
 
Galois’s discoveries led to mathematicians starting to classify ﬁnite simple groups.
 
It was shown that all ﬁnite simple groups belong to one of four inﬁnite families or are
 
one of 26 sporadic groups [
 
27
 
]. The classiﬁcation project can be seen to be started
 
by Otto Hölder’s 1892 article in Mathematische Annalen [
 
16
 
,
 
27
 
]. The ﬁrst stages of
 
group theory are examined before studying the classiﬁcation project in detail.
 
In the late 18th century, Joseph-Louis Lagrange studied polynomial equations. In
 
his study, he considered permutations of the roots of a polynomial [
 
22
 
], which led to a
 
result that is now known as Lagrange’s theorem [
 
20
 
]. At around the same time, Carl
 
Friedrich Gauss studied number theory [
 
13
 
]. He proved that the group of integers
 
modulo a prime
 
p
 
equipped with multiplication,
 
Z
 
×
 
p
 
, is cyclic [
 
13
 
]. Gauss, however,
 
did not approach the problem through group-theoretic terms [
 
20
 
]. Galois, as stated
 
above, introduced theory similar to groups and normal subgroups in 1832 [12, 27].
 
In addition to Lagrange’s classical algebra and Gauss’s number theory, group-
 
theoretic ideas were also used to study geometry [
 
19
 
] and analysis [
 
20
 
,
 
26
 
]. The ﬁrst
 
abstract deﬁnition of a ﬁnite group was given by Arthur Cayley in 1854 in the article
 
On the theory of groups, as depending on the symbolic equation
 
θ
 
n
 
= 1 [
 
6
 
,
 
20
 
]. Cayley
 
presented several examples of groups, and went on to prove that every ﬁnite group is
 
isomorphic to a permutation group, a result now known as Cayley’s theorem [
 
20
 
].
 
Cayley even classiﬁed all groups of order 4 and 6 [6].
 
During the latter half of the 19th century, the concept of an abstract group spread
 
widely [
 
20
 
], and led to several subsequent developments. The Norwegian mathemati-
 
cian Peter Ludvig Sylow in 1872 published his famous theorems on subgroups of
 
prime-power orders [
 
27
 
,
 
29
 
]. The ﬁrst classiﬁcation results are from this era as well,
 
as Camille Jordan began building a database of ﬁnite simple groups in 1870 in Traité
 
des substitutions et des équations algébriques [17, 27].
 
12
 
What accelerated the classiﬁcation eﬀorts was the Jordan–Hölder theorem, pub-
 
lished in 1889, which states that any ﬁnite group can be written as a composition
 
series of simple groups [
 
27
 
]. This theorem allows us to break groups into simple
 
factors similar to how integers are factorised into primes [
 
1
 
]. This allowed mathe-
 
maticians to focus on classifying all simple groups, since non-simple ones can be
 
constructed from them.
 
William Burnside was the ﬁrst to publish a paper classifying an inﬁnite family of
 
ﬁnite simple groups in 1899 [
 
5
 
,
 
27
 
]. Émile Mathieu was the ﬁrst to discover sporadic
 
(a term used originally by Burnside [
 
31
 
]) simple groups,
 
M
 
11
 
and
 
M
 
12
 
, in 1861 [
 
23
 
,
 
31
 
].
 
Sporadic groups are exceptions to the general classiﬁcation, as all ﬁnite simple groups
 
ﬁt into one of the inﬁnite families—apart from sporadic ones [
 
1
 
]. Mathieu later
 
constructed the sporadic groups
 
M
 
22
 
,
 
M
 
23
 
, and
 
M
 
24
 
in 1873 [
 
24
 
]. At the turn of
 
the century, Burnside and Georg Frobenius published multiple classiﬁcation results,
 
including Burnside’s famous
 
p
 
a
 
q
 
b
 
theorem that states that if
 
p
 
and
 
q
 
are primes, then
 
groups of order p
 
a
 
q
 
b
 
are solvable [27].
 
In the 1960s, the general belief was that all ﬁnite simple groups had been found
 
and that it only remained to prove that the list is exhaustive [
 
31
 
]. Over the following
 
decade, twenty-one further sporadic groups were discovered with the last one, the
 
fourth Janko group
 
J
 
4
 
, being discovered in 1975 by Zvonimir Janko. In the year
 
1980, it was once again believed that the classiﬁcation of ﬁnite simple groups was
 
completed [
 
27
 
]. All 26 sporadic groups had been found, and there existed thousands
 
of pages of rigorous mathematical writing proving that any non-sporadic ﬁnite group
 
must belong to one of the inﬁnite families. Around 1989, Michael Aschbacher noticed
 
a ﬂaw related to the handling of so-called quasithin groups. Filling this gap in the
 
theorem proved to be more diﬃcult than Aschbacher and Steve Smith originally
 
ﬁgured. In the end, it took over a decade to patch the theorem.
 
The proof for the classiﬁcation theorem for ﬁnite simple groups (CFSG) was
 
ﬁnally completed in 2004 with two volumes from Aschbacher and Smith [
 
2
 
,
 
3
 
,
 
31
 
].
 
The classiﬁcation theorem states that every ﬁnite simple group is isomorphic to one
 
of the following: a cyclic group of prime order, an alternating group of degree at least
 
5, a simple group of Lie type, or one of 26 sporadic groups [
 
1
 
,
 
28
 
]. The classiﬁcation
 
theorem is considered ‘the most important result in ﬁnite group theory’ [
 
1
 
]. The
 
complete proof, composed of some 500 articles, has been estimated to run between
 
10,000 and 15,000 pages [14].
 
The completion of the CFSG led to deep results in the ﬁeld of permutation theory.
 
The classic problem of classifying multiply-transitive groups followed immediately
 
from the result. However, this exceptionally large ‘proof’ left mathematicians unset-
 
tled. It was the sheer size of the proof of the CFSG that made mathematicians uneasy
 
that it might contain a mistake. To this end, many proofs were being rewritten
 
and simpliﬁed [
 
27
 
]. Furthermore, Daniel Gorenstein, Richard Lyons, and Ronald
 
Solomon started writing a whole new holistic proof for the theorem [
 
1
 
]. Their eﬀort
 
is christened the GLS project by their surnames.
 
While simple groups are fully classiﬁed, classifying arbitrary ﬁnite groups is a
 
diﬀerent matter. Obtaining a general classiﬁcation of ﬁnite groups is considered
 
unattainable, given their intrinsic complexity [
 
10
 
]. Modern developments in ﬁnite
 
13
 
group classiﬁcation often involve using computational methods. The usage and
 
development of algorithms for group classiﬁcation began in the 1990s [
 
10
 
]. During
 
that time, two major group classiﬁcation databases were established: the GAP
 
system [
 
30
 
] and the Magma system [
 
4
 
,
 
10
 
]. These databases have replaced old physical
 
categorisations like John Horton Conway’s ATLAS [
 
7
 
]. One modern example of
 
computer-aided group classiﬁcation is the work of Dietrich et al. on the classiﬁcation
 
of groups whose orders factorise into at most four primes [8].
 
3 Preliminaries
 
3.1 Groups
 
Groups are a fundamental structure in modern algebra. We begin by giving the
 
deﬁnition of a group, presented below. A group is a simple structure that is, in
 
essence, a set equipped with a mapping that satisﬁes certain requirements. An
 
important property of the mapping is that it must map two elements of the set to
 
an element of the set, that is, the mapping must be a binary operation.
 
Deﬁnition 3.1 (Group). A group is a set
 
G
 
equipped with a binary operation
 
· : G × G → G satisfying the following properties:
 
1
 
1. Associativity. For all a, b, c ∈ G, (a · b) · c = a · (b · c).
 
2.
 
Identity. There exists an element
 
e
 
G
 
∈ G
 
such that for all
 
a ∈ G
 
,
 
e
 
G
 
· a
 
=
 
a · e
 
G
 
= a.
 
3.

a
 
−1
 
∈ G

−1
 
=
 
a
 
−1

G
 
.
 
The notation

is used to denote the group consisting of the set
 
G
 
equipped

:
 
G × G → G

of
 
a

words, if the group operation is clear from the context, we use the notations

Deﬁnition 3.3 (Abelian group). A group (

An important type of group is integers modulo some constant under addition.

The following laws are often helpful in simplifying equations.
 
Theorem 3.10 (Cancellation laws). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a group. For all
 
a, b, c ∈ G
 
, we
 
have the following relations:
 
1. Left cancellation law. If a · b = a · c, then b = c.
 
2. Right cancellation law. If b · a = c · a, then b = c.
 
Proof.
 
Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a group. Take any
 
a, b, c ∈ G
 
. Assume

=
 
a · c

)
 
· a
 
−1
 
= (

)
 
· a
 
−1
 
,
 
which simpliﬁes to b = c. This proves the right cancellation law.
 
3.2 Subgroups
 
A group might have subsets of its elements which have a group structure of their own.
 
These subsets are called subgroups. Studying a group’s subgroups often provides
 
valuable insights into the overall structure and properties of the group. Subgroups
 
prove to be an invaluable tool in group classiﬁcation, since if two groups are considered
 
‘the same’, then they must have the same subgroup structure. Conversely, if two
 
groups have diﬀering subgroup structure, then the groups cannot be the same.
 
Deﬁnition 3.11 (Subgroup). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a group. A subset
 
H
 
of
 
G
 
is called a
 
subgroup if itself forms a group under the restricted group operation
 
· |
 
H×H
 
. This is
 
denoted as
 
H ≤ G
 
. If
 
H
 
is a subgroup of group
 
G
 
, we say that
 
G
 
is the overgroup
 
of H.
 
16
 
It is common practice to use the overgroup’s operation for the subgroup as well.
 
Often, it is not necessary to explicitly state the group operation of the subgroup,
 
since it is clear from the context.
 
To verify whether a subset of a group is a subgroup, one needs to check all three
 
‘group axioms’, associativity, existence of identity, and existence of inverses. The
 
following theorem distills this check into two simple conditions.
 
Theorem 3.12 (Subgroup criterion). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a group. The subgroup criterion
 
states the following: a subset
 
H
 
of
 
G
 
is a subgroup if it satisﬁes the following

1. H ̸= ∅,
 
2. For all a, b ∈ H, we have a · b
 
−1
 
∈ H.
 
Proof.
 
Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a group, and let
 
H
 
a subset of
 
G
 
that satisﬁes the two properties
 
from above. We show that
 
H
 
equipped with the restricted group operation

1.

·
 
,
 
the group operation of G.
 
2.

3.4 Cosets
 
Given that groups are closed under the group operation, and that subgroups are
 
non-empty subsets of a group, it is natural to take a subgroup and multiply all of its
 
element by some ﬁxed group element, say, from the right, to produce a subset of the
 
group elements. By the right cancellation law (Theorem 3.10), all subgroup elements
 
now map to diﬀerent group elements. Hence, this operation results in a subset that
 
is the same size as the subgroup. This idea of subsets of the same cardinality is
 
formalised by the deﬁnition of a coset, given below.
 
Deﬁnition 3.26 (Cosets). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a group and
 
H ≤ G
 
a subgroup. For any
 
a ∈ G, we deﬁne the left and right cosets of H as
 
aH = {ah | h ∈ H} and Ha = {ha | h ∈ H} ,
 
respectively.
 
We next formulate the above reasoning on the sizes of cosets into a proposition.
 
Proposition 3.27 (The size of cosets equals size of subgroup). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a ﬁnite
 
group and
 
H ≤ G
 
a subgroup. Then, for each
 
a ∈ G
 
, we have
 
|H|
 
=
 
|aH|

Proof.

One shows that the left (or right) cosets of any subgroup

Since the cosets of a subgroup partition the elements of the group, it is natural

The above results together yield one of the most important theorems in group

Theorem 3.30 (Lagrange’s theorem). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a ﬁnite group and

a

|H|

Lagrange’s theorem has vast consequences, which are signiﬁcant in studying
 
groups’ structure and classifying them. Many of the results are divisibility results,
 
two of which are below.
 
Corollary 3.31 (Subgroup’s order divides group’s order). Let
 
G
 
be a ﬁnite group
 
and H ≤ G a subgroup. We have that |H| divides |G|.
 
Proof. Let G be a group and H ≤ G a subgroup. Theorem 3.30 states that
 
[G : H]|H| = |G|.
 
Thus, |H| is a divisor of |G|.
 
Corollary 3.32 (Element’s order divide’s groups order). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a ﬁnite group.

Proof.

. Now,

by Proposition 3.16.
 
By Corollary 3.31, the order of ⟨a⟩, that is, |⟨a⟩| = |a|, divides |G|. We have shown
 
that |a| divides |G| for all a ∈ G.
 
21

It is possible to deﬁne a group structure on the left cosets of a normal subgroup.

3.6 Isomorphisms
 
Two groups have the same structure if one can be equal to the other by renaming its
 
elements. To classify groups into classes that have the same structure, we need a
 
way to deﬁne an equivalence relation between groups. This relation should indicate
 
whether two groups have the same structure, ignoring what speciﬁc elements they
 
contain. To this end, we deﬁne homomorphisms and isomorphisms.
 
A homomorphism is a mapping between two groups that preserves the group
 
structure. A rigorous deﬁnition is given below.
 
Deﬁnition 3.40 (Homomorphism). Let (
 
G, ·
 
G
 
) and (
 
H, ·
 
H
 
) be two groups. Now, the
 
map f : G → H is called a homomorphism if it satisﬁes the following property
 
f(a ·
 
G
 
b) = f(a) ·
 
H
 
f(b) (1)
 
for all
 
a, b ∈ G
 
. The equation
 
(1)
 
is referred to as the homomorphism property
 
of f.
 
In other words, a mapping from one group to another is a homomorphism if
 
it is compatible with multiplication. Note that it is always possible to construct
 
a homomorphism between two groups. Given groups
 
G
 
and
 
H
 
, the map from
 
G
 
to
 
H
 
deﬁned by
 
g ↦→ e
 
H
 
for all
 
g ∈ G
 
satisﬁes the homomorphism property. This
 
map is called the identity homomorphism or the trivial homomorphism. All other
 
homomorphisms are, then, said to be nontrivial.
 
Deﬁnition 3.41 (Isomorphism). A homomorphism is called an isomorphism if it
 
is bijective.
 
Two groups are said to be isomorphic if there is an isomorphism mapping one to
 
the other. To denote that groups G and H are isomorphic, we write G
 
∼
 
=
 
H.
 
If two groups are isomorphic, they have the same structure. This implies that
 
there are many structural properties of the groups that must match. It is fruitful to
 
state these properties, since when two groups do not match on any of these conditions,
 
we know that they cannot be isomorphic.
 
Theorem 3.42 (Isomorphism properties). Let

and

n

24
 
4. |a| = |ϕ(a)| for all a ∈ G, that is, isomorphism preserves order,

6. ϕ
 
−1
 
: H → G is an isomorphism,
 
7. G is Abelian if and only if H is Abelian.
 
The ﬁrst two of the properties hold for any homomorphism.
 
Proof. We prove each of the properties in order.

The proof for the external direct product being a group is found in Appendix B.
 
External direct products give us a way to construct larger groups from smaller
 
ones. Ideally, we could similarly break apart a larger group into smaller pieces. It is
 
sometimes occasionally possible to do this—using the concept of an internal direct
 
product, deﬁned below. This requires speciﬁc conditions to hold.

We now focus on the actual classiﬁcation of groups. To get started, it is useful to
 
the deﬁne isomorphism classes of groups.
 
28
 
Deﬁnition 3.53 (Isomorphism class of group). Let
 
G
 
be a group. The isomorphism
 
class of G is deﬁned as the class of groups isomorphic to G.
 
Note that any group is isomorphic to itself (by the identity map). Hence, the
 
isomorphism class of any group
 
G
 
contains
 
G
 
itself. We are looking to assign all
 
groups of some order into isomorphism classes. It is, thus, essential to note that
 
isomorphism classes actually do partition groups.
 
Proposition 3.54 (Isomorphism classes partition groups). Every group belongs to
 
some unique isomorphism class, that is, isomorphism classes partition the class of
 
all groups.
 
Proof.
 
To show that isomorphism classes partition the class of all groups, we show
 
that the relation ‘is isomorphic to’ is an equivalence relation. For this, it has to
 
satisfy the following properties
 
1.
 
Reﬂexivity. For any group
 
G
 
, we have
 
G
 
∼
 
=
 
G
 
using the identity isomorphism.
 
2. Symmetry. Let G, H be groups. If G
 
∼
 
=
 
H, then H
 
∼
 
=
 
G by Proposition 3.44.
 
3.
 
Transitivity. Let
 
G, H, K
 
be groups. If
 
G
 
∼
 
=
 
H
 
and
 
H
 
∼
 
=
 
K
 
, then
 
G
 
∼
 
=
 
K
 
by Proposition 3.43.
 
The relation, being an equivalence relation, partitions the class of all groups into
 
(disjoint) isomorphism classes.
 
By Theorem 3.42, two ﬁnite isomorphic groups must have the same order. Thus,
 
any isomorphism class of a ﬁnite group only contains groups of the same order,
 
since one cannot deﬁne a bijection (isomorphism) between two ﬁnite sets (groups) of
 
diﬀerent sizes or from a ﬁnite set to an inﬁnite set.
 
Deﬁnition 3.55. Let
 
n >
 
0 be an integer. To classify groups of order
 
n
 
means
 
to determine all isomorphism classes of groups of order n.
 
To classify groups of certain order
 
n
 
, the above deﬁnition requires us to ﬁnd the
 
isomorphism classes of all groups of the given order. In practice, this is done by
 
giving a representative from each class, showing that this list is comprehensive, and
 
that the given representatives are mutually non-isomorphic. By deﬁnition, these
 
classes contain an isomorphic group for any group of order n.
 
This deﬁnition allows us to start classifying groups. To make things easier, we
 
ﬁrst prove some general classiﬁcation theorems.

4 Classiﬁcation of Groups of Orders 1–10
 
4.1 Groups of Order 1
 
To start oﬀ, we classify groups of order 1. We show that there is only one isomorphism

isomorphic to Z
 
1

5 Tools for Classiﬁcation
 
5.1 Semidirect Products
 
To classify groups of larger orders, we introduce some further results from group theory.
 
Before, we used external direct products to construct large groups from smaller ones.
 
Next, we introduce a generalisation of that: external semidirect products, which are
 
a more expressive tool for generating a wider variety of groups.
 
We ﬁrst state the deﬁnition of the internal semidirect product, and then later
 
prove that all internal semidirect products are isomorphic to external ones.
 
Deﬁnition 5.1 (Internal semidirect product of groups). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a group. We
 
say that G is the internal semidirect product of subgroups H and K if
 
1. G = HK,
 
2. H ∩ K = {e},
 
3. H ◁ G.
 
The ﬁrst condition can be replaced by
 
|G|
 
=
 
|H||K|
 
by Proposition 3.38 and the
 
second by gcd(|H|, |K|) = 1 by Proposition 3.37.
 
Note that the internal semidirect product agrees exactly with the internal direct
 
product (Deﬁnition 3.46) if, in addition to
 
H
 
, the subgroup
 
K
 
is also normal in
 
G
 
.
 
To get started with external semidirect products, we ﬁrst introduce the concept of
 
automorphisms.
 
Deﬁnition 5.2 (Automorphism). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a group. An isomorphism
 
ϕ
 
:
 
G → G
 
is called an automorphism of G if its domain and codomain are G.
 
Theorem 5.3 (Automorphisms form a group). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a group. The set of all
 
automorphisms of
 
G
 
forms a group under the composition operation. This group is
 
denoted by Aut(G).
 
Proof for the above theorem is omitted here, but it is discussed in [11, 15, 18].
 
Theorem 5.4 (Group of units modulo
 
n
 
,
 
Z
 
×
 
n

n
 
.
 
The proof for the above theorem requires results from number theory, and hence,
 
it is omitted here.

5.2 The Sylow Theorems
 
Note that the converse of Lagrange’s theorem (Theorem 3.30) is false: if some integer
 
n
 
divides the order of a group
 
G
 
, then
 
G
 
does not in general have a subgroup of
 
order
 
n
 
. The Sylow theorems, presented below, give a partial converse for Lagrange’s
 
theorem: they show that for some orders, subgroups are guaranteed to exist. These
 
results along with Lagrange’s theorem are the two most important results in ﬁnite
 
group theory [11, 18].
 
We need two deﬁnitions before we can present the Sylow theorems.
 
Deﬁnition 5.10 (Conjugate subgroups). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a group and let
 
H
 
and
 
K
 
be subgroups of
 
G
 
. Now,
 
H
 
and
 
K
 
are said to be conjugate if there exists some
 
element g ∈ G such that
 
H = gKg
 
−1
 
.
 
Deﬁnition 5.11 (Sylow
 
p
 
-subgroup). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a ﬁnite group, and let
 
|G|
 
=
 
p
 
k
 
m
 
for some prime
 
p
 
with
 
gcd
 
(
 
m, p
 
) = 1. Then, any subgroup of
 
G
 
of order
 
p
 
k
 
is called
 
a Sylow p-subgroup of G.
 
We present the Sylow theorems along with some immediate corollaries.
 
Theorem 5.12 (The ﬁrst Sylow theorem). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a ﬁnite group. For any
 
prime p that divides |G|, the group G has a Sylow p-subgroup (Deﬁnition 5.11).
 
Corollary 5.13 (Cauchy’s theorem). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a group of order
 
n
 
. For every
 
prime p that divides n, there exists an element a in G with order p.
 
Proof.
 
Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a group of order
 
n
 
. Let
 
p
 
be a prime that divides
 
n
 
. By the
 
ﬁrst Sylow theorem, there exists a subgroup
 
P
 
of order
 
p
 
. Since
 
P
 
has prime order
 
|P |
 
=
 
p
 
,
 
P
 
is cyclic by Corollary 3.33. Cyclic groups are generated by a single
 
element, hence, there exists an element
 
a
 
in
 
P
 
with order
 
p
 
. Since
 
P ≤ G
 
, we have
 
a ∈ G with |a| = p.
 
Theorem 5.14 (The second Sylow theorem). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a ﬁnite group, and let
 
p
 
be a prime divisor of |G|. Then, any two Sylow p-subgroups of G are conjugate.
 
Theorem 5.15 (The third Sylow theorem). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be a ﬁnite group, and let
 
|G|
 
=
 
p
 
k
 
m
 
for some prime
 
p
 
with
 
gcd
 
(
 
m, p
 
) = 1. Then, the number
 
n
 
p
 
of Sylow
 
p-subgroups of G divides m and satisﬁes n
 
p
 
≡ 1 (mod p).
 
42
 
The proofs for the Sylow theorems are found in Appendix A.
 
Corollary 5.16 (Unique Sylow
 
p
 
-subgroup is normal). Let
 
G
 
be a group with Sylow
 
p
 
-subgroup
 
P
 
. Then,
 
P
 
is normal in
 
G
 
if and only if it is the only Sylow
 
p
 
-subgroup
 
of G.
 
The following result was ﬁrst presented in 1882 by Eugen Netto [25].

5.3 Fundamental Theorem of Finite Abelian Groups
 
Next, follows a very fundamental classiﬁcation result. Using the following theorem,
 
we are able to classify all Abelian groups of any order. The theorem shows that ﬁnite
 
Abelian groups have very speciﬁc structure.
 
Theorem 5.18 (Fundamental Theorem of Finite Abelian Groups). Any ﬁnite Abelian
 
group G is isomorphic to a direct product of cyclic groups of prime-power order:
 
G
 
∼
 
=
 
Z
 
p
 
k
 
1
 
1
 
× Z
 
p
 
k
 
2
 
2
 
× · · · × Z
 
p
 
k
 
n
 
n
 
.
 
Furthermore, any ﬁnite Abelian group is uniquely determined by the number of terms
 
and the orders of the cyclic groups [11].
 
Proof for the fundamental theorem of ﬁnite Abelian groups is omitted. One
 
implication of the theorem is that all ﬁnite groups with more complex structures
 
are non-Abelian. All Abelian groups realise a very regular structure, since they are
 
merely direct products of cyclic groups.
 
Corollary 5.19 (Abelian groups of order 16). By the fundamental theorem of ﬁnite
 
Abelian groups (Theorem 5.18), there are 5 Abelian groups of order 16:
 
Z
 
16

× Z
 
2
 
× Z
 
2
 
× Z
 
2
 
.
 
These are exactly the ways to write 16 as a product of prime powers uniquely up
 
to the number of terms and orders of the factors.

In Chapters 4 and 6, we classiﬁed all groups of orders 1–20, except order 16, up
 
to isomorphism. Table 1 presents an overview of the results. In total, we found
 
54 groups (including the unclassiﬁed groups of order 16), of which 31 are Abelian
 
and 23 are non-Abelian. The number of groups increases with the order. There is a
 
single group of order 2, there are two groups of order four, 5 of order eight, and 14 of
 
50
 
order 16. However, even some large orders have only one isomorphism class. These
 
correspond to prime number orders, which always have only a single isomorphism
 
class.
 
The relative share of non-Abelian groups grows larger as the order increases:
 
Among the 18 groups of orders 1–10, only four (22%), are non-Abelian, and among
 
the 36 groups of orders 11–20, 19 (53%) are non-Abelian. So, for the orders 11–20,
 
over half of the isomorphism classes are non-Abelian. Since Abelian groups have a
 
more regular structure, this indicates that the larger the order, the more freedom
 
there is to diﬀer from this regularity. Groups of small orders tend to have more
 
regular structure. This is further reinforced by the fact that the orders 1–5 give rise
 
only to Abelian groups.
 
Certain group types appeared in groups of diﬀerent orders. A cyclic group
 
isomorphic to
 
Z
 
n
 
can be constructed for any order. This is the simplest possible
 
group structure. The group
 
Z
 
n
 
is Abelian and generated by a single element. Other
 
Abelian groups are found to be isomorphic to direct products of cyclic groups. The
 
ﬁrst occurrence of a direct product is encountered at order 4:
 
Z
 
2
 
× Z
 
2
 
. Another such
 
instance occurs at orders
 
p
 
2
 
, where
 
p
 
is a prime. Each such order includes a group
 
Z
 
p
 
× Z
 
p
 
. This intuition is later conﬁrmed by the complete classiﬁcation of ﬁnite
 
Abelian groups by the fundamental theorem of ﬁnite Abelian groups (Theorem 5.18).
 
The dihedral group
 
D
 
2n
 
is present for even orders, starting from order 6. The
 
smallest dihedral group
 
D
 
6
 
corresponds to the symmetries of a regular triangle, and
 
the larger ones can be thought to extend this idea: they represent symmetries of
 
regular
 
n
 
-gons. Signiﬁcantly, the dihedral groups appear for all even orders, showing
 
that there are inﬁnite families of non-Abelian groups. The presentation we gave for
 
D
 
6
 
generalised for all dihedral groups found, indicating that it could represent all
 
the groups in the family. We also classiﬁed the smallest alternating group:
 
A
 
4
 
. Such
 
recurring group structures conﬁrm that some groups of diﬀerent orders retain similar
 
structure.
 
8 Conclusions and Summary
 
This chapter provides an overview of the classiﬁcation. First, a short recap of the
 
historical account is provided. Then, we draw conclusions from the full classiﬁcation
 
eﬀort, going over each of the tools and theorems that were applied. The structure
 
of the identiﬁed groups and the classiﬁed group families are discussed along with
 
speciﬁc classiﬁcation strategies for outlier orders. Moreover, after limitations and
 
implications of our work are discussed, we conclude with ﬁnal remarks on the thesis.
 
In this thesis, we introduce and motivate the world of group theory. At ﬁrst,
 
some historical background is given for the classiﬁcation eﬀort of ﬁnite groups. Then,
 
important structures are deﬁned along with fundamental theorems related to groups.
 
These structures and theorems are then used to classify the groups of orders 1–20
 
into isomorphism classes. We then recap the classiﬁcation of all these groups into
 
one, and provide insights into the full classiﬁcation.
 
The study of groups started in the 18th century through Lagrange’s study of
 
51
 
polynomial equations. After group-theoretic ideas were also applied to number
 
theory and geometry, Évariste Galois introduced simple groups in 1832, which led to
 
the development of ﬁnite group theory in the late 19th century. The introduction
 
of the Jordan–Hölder theorem started a project of classifying all simple groups in
 
1889. It took over a century of work to classify all ﬁnite simple groups into inﬁnite
 
families or classify them as one of the 26 exceptions. In 2004, the classiﬁcation of
 
ﬁnite simple groups was ﬁnally completed—with a gargantuan proof spanning over
 
10,000 pages. The completion of the classiﬁcation project is a major milestone in
 
mathematics. While ﬁnite simple groups are fully classiﬁed, arbitrary ﬁnite groups
 
remain unclassiﬁed due to their intrinsic complexity. However, many databases of
 
concrete classiﬁcations of ﬁnite groups exist, such as GAP and Magma [4, 30].
 
8.1 Summary of Classiﬁcation of Orders 1–10
 
Starting from the deﬁnition of a group, we ﬁrst deﬁned what it means for two groups
 
to have the same structure, that is, to be isomorphic. Isomorphisms yield a natural
 
way to examine the structural similarity of two groups. This deﬁnition of ‘sameness’
 
is core for the classiﬁcation work of this thesis. We later showed that groups that are
 
isomorphic share many structural elements: for instance, the orders of the elements
 
of two isomorphic groups match, one group is Abelian only if the one it is isomorphic
 
to is. It was shown that isomorphisms divide all groups into isomorphism classes. To
 
classify groups, then, is to ﬁnd all isomorphism classes, providing an explicit example
 
of each class.
 
To be able to classify groups into isomorphism classes, we introduced structures
 
such as subgroups, cosets, and quotient groups. These allow us to better understand
 
the structure of groups. Subgroups give a way to extract smaller group structures
 
from large groups. Cosets provide a way to split all elements of the original group
 
into disjoint classes based on their relation to a certain subgroup. Quotient groups
 
are another way to establish new structure from a subgroup. These structures are
 
further deployed for proving important theorems such as Lagrange’s theorem and
 
Sylow’s theorems.
 
For constructing new groups, internal and external direct products are introduced.
 
Internal direct products are a speciﬁc way to represent the group as a product of
 
its normal subgroups. We showed that internal direct products are isomorphic to
 
external ones, which gives a way to split a group into direct product factors, given
 
there is a way to represent it as an internal product of normal subgroups. External
 
direct products behave well with isomorphisms. For instance, changing the order of
 
the factors keeps the product the same up to isomorphism. Moreover, changing any
 
of the factors does not aﬀect the result, either.
 
Groups of orders 1–10 were classiﬁed using three diﬀerent techniques. Firstly,
 
groups of prime orders were classiﬁed to be cyclic. There is only one isomorphism
 
class for any prime order. This is due to the divisibility of primes. Lagrange’s
 
theorem implies that the order of all group elements must divide the order of the
 
group. Since primes are only divisible by 1 and themselves, this restricts the orders
 
of the elements in the group to two choices. The deﬁnition of the order of an element
 
52
 
implies that non-identity elements must have order greater than 1.
 
Secondly, groups of order
 
p
 
2
 
were identiﬁed to have two isomorphism classes: the
 
cyclic group and the direct product of two cyclic groups of order
 
p
 
. This is a major
 
classiﬁcation result, since it allows for classifying an inﬁnite family of groups. Again,
 
the result is ultimately due to the number-theoretic structure of the order. It is
 
clear that all orders have cyclic groups. To see that the only other option is a direct
 
product of two equally-sized cyclic groups, we again rely on Lagrange’s theorem. It
 
shows that elements of order
 
p
 
must exist in the group. The subgroups generated by
 
such elements allow us to express the whole group as an internal direct product of
 
two such subgroups. This internal direct product, then, is isomorphic to an external
 
one, which leads to the representation of the group as a direct product of two cyclic
 
groups.
 
Finally, the orders 6, 8, and 10 are classiﬁed using case-by-case work. To ﬁnd the
 
structure of the group, it is necessary to know its elements. For this, we showed that
 
an element of order
 
n/
 
2 exists in the group. Then, the subgroup generated by this
 
element contains half the elements in the group. The other half is exactly contained
 
in the only other coset of this subgroup. This gives a way to represent each item
 
in the group. This construction already ﬁxes the values of some products between
 
the group items. For the remaining relations between the group elements, we made
 
assumptions, and showed that those eventually led to either a fully determined group
 
structure or a contradiction.
 
8.2 Summary of Classiﬁcation of Orders 11–20
 
For the classiﬁcation of groups of orders 11–20, new structures were presented.
 
External direct products were powerful for classifying and representing Abelian groups.
 
To extend this idea to non-Abelian groups, semidirect products are introduced. An
 
internal semidirect product does not require all of the subgroups to be normal.
 
Similarly to the internal direct products, internal semidirect products are isomorphic
 
to their external equivalents. External semidirect products have the same group
 
elements as direct products, but work with a diﬀerent group operation that requires a
 
homomorphism from the second factor to the automorphism group of the ﬁrst factor.
 
This homomorphism ‘twists’ the items from the ﬁrst factor, yielding non-Abelian
 
results even from Abelian factors.
 
In order to better study the structure of larger non-Abelian groups, the Sylow
 
theorems were presented. The Sylow theorems give a partial converse for Lagrange’s
 
theorem. While Lagrange’s theorem states that the order of each subgroup divides the
 
order of the group, the ﬁrst Sylow theorem shows that there has to exist a subgroup
 
for some divisors of the order of the group. This eases the study of large groups,
 
since we immediately know something about their structure. The divisors for which
 
the Sylow theorems show the existence of subgroups are powers of primes. Hence, as
 
with many others, this result is, again, related to the prime-factor decomposition
 
of the order of the group. The third Sylow theorem gives strict requirements for
 
the number of so-called Sylow
 
p
 
-subgroups, which are helpful in assessing whether a
 
subgroup found using the ﬁrst Sylow theorem is normal.
 
53
 
We then present the fundamental theorem of Abelian groups that encapsulates
 
complete classiﬁcation of all ﬁnite Abelian groups. The theorem states that Abelian
 
groups have a certain, regular structure: they are all external direct products of
 
cyclic groups of prime-power order. This simpliﬁes our classiﬁcation work, and builds
 
certainty on the classiﬁcation of Abelian groups of smaller orders.
 
Many of the orders from 11–20 are classiﬁed using the same techniques as for
 
orders 1–10. However, using the theory of semidirect products we classiﬁed a new
 
inﬁnite family: groups of order
 
pq
 
where
 
p
 
and
 
q
 
are primes. The idea is to break
 
up the group into smaller pieces—similar to the classiﬁcation of groups of order
 
p
 
2
 
.
 
We show that the group can be represented as an internal semidirect product of
 
two of its subgroups. This internal semidirect product is, then, isomorphic to an
 
external semidirect product, where the choice of the homomorphism gives us diﬀerent
 
isomorphism classes. The trivial homomorphism, corresponding to the external
 
direct product of the factors, always exists, but additionally, if
 
p | q −
 
1, we ﬁnd a
 
non-trivial homomorphism as well, yielding a non-Abelian group.
 
Some orders of groups still do not fall into any of the inﬁnite families of groups
 
we have classiﬁed. These are exactly the orders that cannot be represented as any of
 
the following:
 
p
 
,
 
p
 
2
 
,
 
pq
 
. For these orders a more general strategy is employed, where
 
we identify the existence of a Sylow
 
p
 
-subgroup based on the prime decomposition of
 
the order of the group. We then show that this subgroup is normal, which allows us
 
to represent the group as an internal semidirect product. This internal semidirect
 
product is isomorphic to an external semidirect product, which gives diﬀerent groups
 
based on the homomorphism it is equipped with. If the homomorphism is non-trivial,
 
we ﬁnd non-Abelian groups, since the trivial homomorphism always corresponds
 
to the external direct product. Diﬀerent non-trivial homomorphisms may generate
 
diﬀerent groups, but it is important not to include any two isomorphic groups.
 
8.3 Limitations
 
One limitation of the work is the restriction to groups of certain orders. Since the
 
possible group structures depend heavily on the prime-decomposition of the order, it
 
is fruitful to consider a variety of diﬀerent orders. The numbers from 1–20 are all
 
products of powers of at most two primes. Hence, in this work, we do not present any
 
classiﬁcation for a group whose order is a product of powers of three distinct primes,
 
like 30 or 42. Classifying groups of more complex orders would help generalise results
 
and deepen the understanding of the possible structures.
 
Many tools are provided in the thesis for the classiﬁcation of groups. The
 
implications and applications of these tools are not fully explored within the scope
 
of this work. Semidirect products are only brieﬂy introduced and then applied to
 
classiﬁcation. To be able to use semidirect products, we need the deﬁnition of an
 
automorphism. However, the world of automorphisms is barely explored in the work.
 
Understanding automorphisms on a deeper level would help in constructing and
 
analysing semidirect products.
 
In this work, we rely on our classiﬁcation results without doing algorithmic
 
veriﬁcation for the classiﬁcation. Computer systems such as GAP [
 
30
 
] could be used
 
54
 
to check that the computations and the ﬁnal classiﬁcation are in line with an existing
 
database. Algorithmic classiﬁcation would also provide insight into the structure of
 
larger groups than studied here. It would allow applying the results, such as the
 
Sylow theorems, to a more general set of groups.
 
8.4 Discussion
 
It is relatively simple to classify groups of orders up to 10, since for orders up to
 
10, the maximum number of groups of a single order is 5. However, the complexity
 
of classiﬁcation increases with the order. For groups up to order 20, there exist 14
 
groups of order 16. This increase in complexity makes the classiﬁcation task more
 
laborious and error-prone. Interestingly, the highest increase in order is observed
 
with powers of two. This indicates that the repeated prime factors in the prime-
 
decomposition of the order give rise to unseen complexity. This means the higher the
 
order, the more diﬃcult the classiﬁcation. For arbitrarily large groups, classiﬁcation
 
is near-impossible.
 
Even if the classiﬁcation of larger groups is a diﬀerent task, it uses the same ideas
 
from smaller orders. The methods needed for understanding the classiﬁcation of
 
small groups generalise to classifying larger groups. All of the tools and theorems
 
provided in this thesis are not speciﬁc to small orders, but rather can be applied
 
to ﬁnite groups of any orders. Especially, the more powerful results like the Sylow
 
theorems show their true power when used for even larger groups. It is possible to
 
represent every group of orders 1–20 as a semidirect product, which proves the wide
 
applicability of the technique.
 
The groups of orders 1–20 are elementary knowledge in group theory. Still, it
 
is fruitful to understand their inner structure well. Since there are many tools for
 
breaking a group apart into smaller pieces, a solid grasp of the structure of small
 
groups can help in analysing larger groups. There are many patterns that repeat for
 
larger and larger orders. This is visible in the construction of inﬁnite group families:
 
understanding and deriving the smallest dihedral group
 
D
 
6
 
gives a concrete basis on
 
top of which to build theory of the general case D
 
2n
 
.
 
All groups up to order 20, except for order 16, are now presented and examined, in
 
increasing order of
 
n
 
. Their structures were derived starting from
 
n
 
using foundational
 
tools such as Lagrange’s theorem, Sylow theorems, and semidirect products. These
 
tools, along with the classiﬁcation, oﬀer a viewpoint into the world of ﬁnite groups.

A Proofs for the Sylow Theorems
 
In this appendix, we present proofs for the three Sylow theorems. For proving the
 
Sylow theorems, we introduce some new deﬁnitions.
 
A.1 Centralisers, Centres, and Normalisers
 
We ﬁrst deﬁne the centraliser of a group element, and the centre of the group.
 
Deﬁnition A.1 (Centraliser). Let (

) be a group and let

of a consists of the elements in G that a commutes with:
 
C
 
G
 
(a) = {g ∈ G | ga = ag} .

Theorem A.2 (Centralisers are subgroups). Let (

Next, we deﬁne the centre of a group.

Proof.

Note that subgroups of the centre are normal, since the centre consists exactly of
 
the elements that commute with every element of G.
 
Proposition A.5 (Subgroups of the centre are normal). Let (

) be a group and

This result yields the following corollary.
 
Corollary A.6 (Subgroups of Abelian groups are normal). Let (
 
G, ·
 
) be an Abelian
 
group, and let H be a subgroup of G. Then, H ◁ G.
 
Proof.
 
For Abelian group

(

G
 
. Hence,
 
any subgroup of G is normal in G by Proposition A.5.

There is a natural way to partition a set based on ‘reachability’ through the

A.3 The Sylow Theorems
 
For proving the ﬁrst Sylow theorem, we show a relaxed version of the well-known
 
Cauchy’s theorem. This result only holds for Abelian groups.
 
Theorem A.23 (Cauchy’s theorem for Abelian groups). Let
 
G
 
be a ﬁnite Abelian
 
group, and let p be a prime. If p divides |G|, then G has an element of order p.
 
63
 
Proof.
 
Fix a prime

Base case. The base case is

p
